Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Expectation2: Prepare sermons and deliver weekly messages during Shabbat services.
Situation2: A sermon must be delivered for a High Holiday service, which the entire congregation is expected to attend.
Story: I glance at my calendar, heart pounding. The team meeting is in ten minutes—a routine catch-up, but my manager expects everyone to participate, to show we’re engaged. I know it’ll be recorded, but there’s always that unspoken pressure to be present, to contribute in real time. At the same moment, my mind is racing with unfinished thoughts for the High Holiday sermon. The congregation is counting on me; this isn’t just any Shabbat, but a service where every word matters, where people seek comfort and inspiration. I can almost hear their voices, see their faces, feel the weight of their expectations. My colleagues expect reliability, my congregation expects spiritual leadership. I sit at my desk, torn, the meeting link open on one screen, my sermon notes on the other. My hands tremble as I try to focus, but the demands of both worlds pull me in opposite directions, and I feel the tension rising, knowing I can’t be fully present for both.
